content: The "Access to Emergency Medical Services Act of 2007" establishes a Bipartisan Commission on Access to Emergency Medical Services and provides additional payments for certain physicians' services. It also requires hospitals and critical access facilities to report on certain emergency department information. The United States Bipartisan Commission on Access to Emergency Medical Services is established to report information on certain emergency department information as a condition of Medicare participation. The Commission is tasked with identifying factors affecting the delivery of screening and stabilization services in hospitals with emergency departments under EMTALA. It must make recommendations to Congress on federal programs and policies to ensure the availability of these services and coordinate disaster response programs. Factors to be considered include those specified in subsection (b). The Commission will examine factors related to emergency departments of hospitals, including crowded conditions, patient boarding, barriers to access for emergency medical treatment, and legal and financial liability of healthcare professionals. The Commission will consider changes in Federal law, funding sources, and alternative approaches to protect healthcare professionals and providers from legal and financial liability regarding emergency medical services under EMTALA. The Commission will consider establishing Federal limits on liability for emergency medical services under EMTALA, superseding conflicting State laws. Coordination of State, local, and Federal programs for emergency medical services during disasters and emergencies will be addressed. Definitions for terms like "hospital" will be clarified. The term "EMTALA" refers to section 1867 of the Social Security Act (42 U.S.C. 1395dd). SEC. 103. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of 18 members appointed within 60 days of the enactment of the Act. The President, Speaker of the House, and Senate majority leader each appoint six members. The Commission, consisting of 18 members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, and Senate majority leader, includes representatives of physicians, elected officials, and health care consumer advocates. The Commission elects a chairman and four vice chairmen from its members, with each member serving for the life of the Commission. Vacancies are filled as needed. The Commission consists of 18 members appointed by various officials and includes representatives of physicians, elected officials, and health care consumer advocates. Vacancies are filled for the remainder of the term, and members serve without pay but are reimbursed for travel expenses. The Commission consists of 18 members appointed by various officials, including physicians, elected officials, and health care consumer advocates. Vacancies are filled for the remainder of the term, and members serve without pay but are reimbursed for travel expenses. A quorum for the Commission consists of nine members, with six members able to conduct a hearing. Meetings are called by the chairman or a majority of members. SEC. 104. STAFF AND CONSULTANTS. The Commission may appoint staff and consultants without following certain provisions of the United States Code. Consultants can be hired at specific rates to assist in carrying out the Commission's duties. The Commission can request Federal agencies to detail personnel to assist in carrying out its duties, without affecting their civil service status or privileges. SEC. 105. POWERS. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence as needed. The Comptroller General can conduct studies upon request, and the Congressional Budget Office can provide cost estimates when requested. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, receive evidence, and request technical assistance from Federal agencies. They can also use the United States mails and obtain information directly. The Congressional Budget Office will be reimbursed for expenses related to additional staff needed for cost estimate development. The Commission can obtain information from Federal agencies, receive administrative support services, accept donations, and be considered a committee of Congress for printing purposes. The Commission will submit a report to Congress on ways to promote effective delivery of emergency medical services, including recommendations to remove barriers. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting the report, with authorization of appropriations for necessary funds. Additionally, there will be additional payments for certain physicians' services. The Social Security Act is amended to provide additional payment for physicians' services furnished in the emergency department of a hospital pursuant to EMTALA. This payment is equal to 10 percent of the payment amount for the services under this part. The amendment made by subsection (a) shall apply to services furnished on or after January 1, 2008. Title III requires hospitals to report certain emergency department information as a condition of Medicare participation. Title III of the Social Security Act requires hospitals to report emergency department information to the Secretary for Medicare participation. Title III of the Social Security Act mandates hospitals with emergency departments to annually report the average admission period to the Secretary for Medicare participation, starting from 2008. Hospitals with emergency departments must report the average admission period to the Secretary for Medicare participation, starting from 2008. The report should include the time from when the patient arrives at the hospital to when they reach their definitive inpatient destination. The Secretary will disclose this information on the Department of Health and Human Services website for public comparison among hospitals. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will determine whether a quality measure should be developed for hospitals based on information reported under the Social Security Act. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will determine if a quality measure should be developed for hospitals based on reported information under the Social Security Act. The quality measure for a hospital in a year is a measure regarding the average admission period. The quality measure for a hospital in a year is a measure regarding the average admission period described in the Social Security Act.
